Project Description  The outputs  of the  Project will be as  follows: (i) establishment of a 
  modern treasury with a nationwide network of treasury offices servicing 
budgetary organizations of national and subnational governments and 
revenue  collection  agencies,  and  development  of  a  functioning 
government  financial  management  information  system  (GFMIS)  to 
facilitate treasury operations; (ii) consolidated and streamlined treasury 
banking  operations  under  the  established  treasury  single  account 
(TSA); (iii) creation of a central accounting system using a unified chart 
of accounts (COA) in line with the revised budget classification, the 
International Monetary Fund’s (IMF’s) Government Finance Statistics 
Manual  (GFSM  2001)  and  International  Public  Sector  Accounting 
Standards (IPSAS); (iv) a refined legal framework; and (v) application 
of  the  revised  budget  classification  to  the  budget  preparation  and 
execution with improved pilot program budgeting in selected sectors. 
 
The Project will have the following three components: (i) establishment 
of a nationwide institutional network of treasury offices and support for 
capacity  building;  (ii)  modernization  of  treasury  operations;  and  (iii) 
project management, monitoring, and evaluation. 
 
The first component will provide assistance in establishing a nationwide 
institutional network of treasury offices and associated capacity building 
in the areas where gaps are identified and the needs are acute. In 
particular, the capacity building will include support to build Ministry of 
Finance  (MOF)  capacity  in  the  maintenance  of  the  GFMIS  and 
management of associated databases.

ii   
  The second component will comprise development and implementation 
of  a  GFMIS.  It  will  provide  financing  for  (i) procurement, setting  of 
parameters,  installation  and  deployment  of  an  integrated  treasury 
software  application  package  with  associated  documentation  and 
training services; (ii) supply of main servers for the central treasury 
office and a back-up processing center in Tashkent; (iii) supply of the 
computers and networking items to equip the treasury offices being 
established  throughout  Uzbekistan;  (iv)  procurement  of 
telecommunications equipment; and (v) local area networking, including 
dedicated  local  telecommunication  lines,  local  area  network 
infrastructure, power supply, monitoring, and alarm systems for local 
offices. 
 
  The  third  component  will  comprise  establishment  of  a  project 
  management office (PMO) under  MOF to manage day-to-day project 
activities. The PMO will work in close cooperation with MOF, Treasury, 
and its offices at central and local levels. 
 
Rationale   The  proposed  Project  is  in  line  with  the  principles  of  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB) country strategy and  program (CSP)  for 
Uzbekistan, endorsed by ADB’s Board  of Directors in March 2006. It 
aims to support the country’s transition to a market-based economy 
and promote good governance. Uzbekistan has recently developed a 
public finance management (PFM) reform strategy which outlines an 
action plan for the next 12 years to (i) establish a functioning treasury 
system,  (ii)  adopt  and  implement  a  modern  unified  budget  and 
accounting  system,  and  (iii)  introduce  a  medium-term  budget 
framework (MTBF) and program budgeting. The Project will provide 
support mainly for implementing  and refining the PFM strategy.  The 
PFM reform will have significant implications for the country’s economic 
management, leading to more effective and efficient  management of 
public  resources.  The  proposed  Project  will  also  provide  a  good 
foundation for future dialogue and cooperation between the authorities 
and ADB in further PFM reform over the next 10–12 years.   
   
Impact and Outcome  The project impact will be improved planning and utilization of public 
resources.  The  project  outcome  will  be  improved  effectiveness, 
efficiency,  transparency  and  accountability  of  budget  execution 
processes.  The  Project  impact  and  outcome  will  be  monitored and 
measured mainly by the performance indicators as described in paras. 
9–10 of the main text, and  the design and monitoring framework in 
Appendix 1.  
 
   
Project Investment Plan  The investment cost of the Project is estimated at $37.36 million. The 
cost estimates include $3.95 million for taxes and duties, $1.28 million 
for physical and price contingencies, and estimated financing charges 
during implementation (comprising interest during implementation and 
a commitment charge) of $2.61 million.

iii 
Financing Plan  A loan of $20.70 million from  ADB’s ordinary capital resources will be 
provided under ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based 
lending facility. The loan will have a 25-year term including a grace 
period of 4 years, an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s 
LIBOR-based  lending  facility,  a  commitment  charge  of  0.35%  per 
annum  on  undisbursed  loan  amount,  and  such  other  terms  and 
conditions set forth in the draft loan agreement. The Borrower will be 
the  Republic  of  Uzbekistan.  The  requested  level  of  financing  will 
comprise 55% of the total project cost. The Government will contribute 
$16.66  million  toward  the  project  cost,  including  $10  million  for 
financing refurbishment of treasury offices nationwide, $2.61 million for 
financing charges during implementation, and $3.95 million in taxes 
and duties.

Implementation  The  Project  will  be  implemented  over  a  period  of  4  years.  Project 
Arrangements  activities will include the selection of a vendor for development and 
installation of the GFMIS, procurement of hardware and networking 
equipment,  and  development  and  implementation  of  a  project 
performance monitoring and evaluation system. The  establishment of 
the treasury institutional network and support for  capacity building in 
budget reform will be implemented in line with progress in development 
and implementation of the GFMIS.  
 
Procurement  Goods  and  services  will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). The 
Government will furnish a project procurement plan for ADB approval. 
The Government will implement the procurement plan as approved by 
ADB, and  will update the procurement plan annually, or as needed. 
ADB  will  disclose  the  plan  and  its  updates  to  the  public  after  the 
approval of related financing. Major contracts to be financed by ADB’s 
loan  for  information  technology  (IT)  software  and  equipment  and

international competitive bidding (ICB).

iv

$10,000, the Executing Agency (EA) may purchase the items directly 
from the supplier. In such cases, ADB should be satisfied that the price

  All goods and services financed by the loan will be procured from ADB

Consulting Services  About 10 IT specialists from MOF will be trained in the following areas: 
(i) database administration, (ii) operational systems engineering, and 
(iii) network technology engineering. The training and certification will 
be  provided  during  the  first  year  of  project  implementation  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended from time to time), under a contract between the PMO and an 
authorized  IT  certification  company  engaged  on  the  basis  of 
consultant’s qualifications selection method.  
 
An international IT and procurement consultant will provide 8 person-
months  of  consultancy  input  to  assist  the  PMO  in  conducting  ICB 
procurements  of  the  various  GFMIS  components,  in  particular  the 
development and implementation of the GFMIS software (procurement 
package 1). MOF will engage an individual international consultant in 
accordance with ADB procedures for recruiting individual consultants.  
 
Technical Assistance  The  outcome  of  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  project  will  be 
strengthened capacity of the Government in budget preparation and 
execution using the revised budget classification. The TA project will 
address the immediate capacity-building needs and focus on the areas 
not covered by other donors either now or in the near future. 
 
The  TA  project  will  have  two  components:  (i)  support  for  budget 
preparation,  and  (ii)  support  for  budget  execution  through  treasury 
operations using the GFMIS. The  TA project outputs will comprise (i) 
development  of  user  manuals  on  budget  preparation  and  treasury 
operation under the revised budget classifications; (ii) development of 
training modules and materials in budget preparation and execution 
using the revised budget classification system; (iii) development of 
performance indicators for the education sector; and (iv) training of 17 
staff from MOF Treasury, Budget Department, and Treasury Training 
Center  in  budget  preparation  and  budget  execution  based  on  the 
revised budget classification.

v 
  The TA project will be implemented over a period of 24 months, starting 
in January 2008. MOF will be the EA for the TA project. MOF Budget 
Department  will  be  the  main  counterpart  for  budget  preparation 
activities while the Treasury will coordinate the budget execution. The 
TA project will require  international (24 person-months) and national 
(48 person-months) consultants with the following areas of expertise: (i) 
performance-based  budget  preparation,  and  (ii)  budget  execution 
through  treasury  operations.  The  consultants  will  be  selected  and 
engaged by ADB in accordance with ADB procedures for recruiting 
individual consultants. 
 
Project Benefits and  The major benefits of the Project will be indirect, and will be reflected in 
Beneficiaries  (i) improved budget quality, (ii) budget execution efficiency and linkage 
between budgeting and policy objectives as well as program outcomes, 
(iii) greater transparency and accountability in PFM, underpinned by the 
established treasury institutional network and modern treasury system; 
and  (iv)  progress  in  the  introduction  of  the  MTBF  and  program 
budgeting. Direct economic benefits of the Project  will be the savings 
derived  from  better  cash  management  and  thus  reduced  interest 
payments. 
 
Beneficiaries of the Project will include (i) policy makers and institutions 
who,  with  the  help  of  the  modern  treasury,  will  be  able  to  make 
decisions and, if necessary, fiscal adjustments, based on  the timely 
availability of better-classified information; (ii) stakeholders, including the 
general public and parliament, who will  be able to better assess and 
monitor the effect of the PFM; and (iii) the general public, who will 
benefit  from  the  provision  of  public  goods  and  services  that  are 
facilitated by improved payment and budget execution processes. 
  
Risks and  The continued Government commitment to, and ownership of, the PFM 
Assumptions  reform will be crucial for the Project’s success and the achievement of 
the intended outcome and impact. This is especially true when reform 
in the MTBF and program budgeting becomes further advanced. It is 
recognized that this is a long-term, complex task and sometimes an 
iterative process, and will require institutional changes and significant 
capacity building of relevant institutions, especially in formulation of 
sector policies and development of performance indicators to measure 
and  monitor  the  effect  of  the  reform.  Currently,  the Government is 
receiving  assistance  in  this  area  from  United  Nations  Development 
Programme (UNDP) and European Union Technical Assistance to the 
Commonwealth of Independent States (TACIS). It is unclear to date 
whether this assistance will be adequate, as the needs may evolve. 
Consequently this will be one of the main areas for future dialogue 
between the Government and ADB. Depending on the country’s needs 
and  the  implementation  of  other  development-partner  programs  in 
capacity  building,  ADB  will  design  its  future  program  in  this  area 
accordingly.

vi   
  Another risk is that staff assigned to the newly established treasury 
offices will be inadequately skilled. To mitigate this risk, a targeted 
training program is planned. This program will be carefully sequenced 
in line with the progress in development and implementation of the 
GFMIS, and will include provisions that will help prevent the loss of key 
trained staff. Ongoing and planned commitment by other development 
partners in this area will also help mitigate the risks. 
 
Frequent turnover of PMO staff is a potential risk. ADB will work with 
the Government  to  minimize  staff  turnover  and  ensure  the  PMO  is 
equipped with competent, full-time staff. 
 
  Effective coordination with development partners will be important to 
meet  the  country’s  long-term  needs  for  capacity  building.  Such 
coordination during the project preparation stage has been very good; 
ADB  will  work  to  maintain  close  cooperation.  The  fact  that  ADB’s 
Uzbekistan Resident Mission is leading the  project preparation and 
implementation will help the coordination.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of Uzbekistan for the Public Finance Management Reform Project.1 The report 
also  describes  the  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  supporting  public  finance 
management (PFM) reforms. If the Board of Directors of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by  the Board, will 
approve the TA.  
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Uzbekistan is the most populous country in the Central Asia region and has the second-
largest economy.  Located strategically in the center of the region, it borders the  four other 
Central Asian countries, and Afghanistan. It is one of the few “double land-locked” countries in 
the world (i.e., surrounded only by other landlocked countries). Uzbekistan has abundant natural 
resources, including gold, natural gas, copper and uranium. It has an economy dominated by 
agriculture,  with  almost  70%  of  the  population  living  in  rural  areas.  It  also  has  a  young 
population, with more than 50% of the people under the age of 19.   
 
3.  At  independence  in  1991,  Uzbekistan  inherited  a  difficult  economic  situation.  The 
economy then underwent significant changes, declining considerably until 1996 when it began 
to show some modest growth. Economic growth has accelerated during 2004-2006. The gross 
domestic product (GDP) grew by 7.3% on average  during this period, compared with 4.2% 
during 1999–2003. Favorable external prices of Uzbekistan’s major exports and real growth of 
noncommodity exports  have contributed  to  this  recent  growth. However, economic growth 
remains narrowly based and the economy has yet to realize its growth potential. Uzbekistan 
remains a low-income country, with per capita GDP estimated at $606 in 2006.  
 
4.  The economy experienced significant macroeconomic imbalances until 2000. Since then 
macroeconomic management has improved; monetary policies were tightened and distortions in 
exchange rates reduced, leading to unification of exchange rates and the introduction of current 
account convertibility in October 2003. However, the overall progress in macroeconomic and 
structural reforms has been mixed. There are many daunting challenges facing the country in 
carrying out economic reforms, especially in the banking and trade sectors.  
 
5.  Progress on the fiscal reform has been encouraging. Lending from the Central Bank of 
Uzbekistan (CBU) to the budget has been discontinued. Government expenditure has been 
reduced from 45% of GDP in 1998 to about 32% in 2006. After reaching 10% of GDP in 1998–
1999, fiscal deficits were subsequently reduced significantly and have been largely eliminated 
since 2004. Debt levels have improved with the adoption of prudent fiscal policy and a zero-net-
borrowing strategy. A more detailed sector and subsector analysis is given in Appendix 2. 
  
6.  After a number of years of piloting various elements of fiscal reforms, the Government 
has adopted a long-term strategic approach to advancing the reform process. In May 2007, the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF) developed a PFM reform strategy for 2007–2018 (Appendix 3) with 
support from the IMF Fiscal Affairs Department and ADB. The strategy outlines an action plan

for the next 12 years  which will (i) establish a functioning  treasury system; (ii) adopt and 
implement a modern, unified budget and accounting system; and (iii) introduce a medium-term 
budget framework (MTBF) and program budgeting. 
 
7.  A  central  element  of  the  PFM reform  is  to  improve the budget execution process 
significantly over the next 5 years. The PFM reform strategy has planned to set up a nationwide 
network of treasury offices with a central treasury in MOF, local treasury departments at the 
regional2 (oblast) level and branches at the district (rayon) level. These  treasury offices will 
provide services to the budget organizations of both national and subnational governments. It is 
also planned to  consolidate the currently fragmented treasury  banking  operations  under a 
treasury single account (TSA) at the CBU, to be supported by the computerized GFMIS. 
 
8.  The  PFM  reform  will  have  significant  implications  for  the  country’s  economic 
management. As envisaged by the strategy, the focus of the reform over the medium term (3–5 
years) will be mainly on improving the efficiency, effectiveness, transparency, and accountability 
of the budget execution process. Over the long term (10–12 years) the reform will gradually 
move its focus to improving the results of the budget. 
 
9.  Key performance indicators to measure and monitor the progress and achievement of 
the reform objective over the medium term include (i) the existence of a clear annual budget 
calendar, (ii)  the requirement of  appropriation of  public expenditure by parliament, (iii)  the 
adoption  of  an  expenditure  commitment  control  scheme  that  can  effectively  limit  the 
commitments  to  actual  cash  availability  to  approved  budget  allocations  for  most  types  of 
expenditure, and (iv) the preparation and regular update of cash flow forecasts on the basis of 
actual cash inflows and outflows.  
  
10.  Key performance indicators over the long term include (i) linkage between budget and 
policy objectives and programs; (ii)  budget preparation and allocation made with a multi-year 
perspective based on reasonable forecasts of major fiscal aggregate for the next 3 years; (iii) 
inclusion of cost implications in the preparation of  selected sector strategies; and (iv) annual 
publication of an approved and executed budget with a gradual increase in the coverage and 
content, moving toward greater uniformity with international standards and including economic, 
functional, administrative, and program classifications, as well as underlying policy assumptions. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Key Problems 
11.  Budget  Preparation.  Uzbekistan  inherited  the  budget  preparation  process  that  is 
common to all other countries that were part of the former Soviet Union.  Currently, budget 
entities prepare their budget requests largely on the basis of previous inputs rather according to 
clear policies and policy objectives linked  to defined  programs with performance indicators. 
MOF receives budget requests from a large number of budget agencies, many of which lack 
capacity  in  making  policy  choices.  MOF  reviews  the  budget  requests  in  terms  of  their 
consistency  with  current  regulations,  and  applies  cuts  mainly  to  the  fourth  category  of 
expenditure,3 which often leads to a lack of funds for maintenance and current supplies.  The

available time and data do not give MOF the opportunity to undertake in-depth analysis of the

12.  Until recently the budget also suffered from the lack of a medium-term perspective, such 
as  a  medium-term  fiscal  framework  (MTFF)  that  would  project  important  macroeconomic 
variables—including GDP, balance of payments, inflation, and interest rates—over a 3–5-year 
period. Such an MTFF would form the basis for more reliable revenue estimates. In conjunction 
with the  Government’s deficit target, these revenue estimates would  (i) establish an overall 
spending limit, (ii) allow for the establishment of sector spending limits, and (iii) enable the 
development of a coherent and sustainable aggregate and sector expenditure policy. In effect 
there are two budget preparation processes: the first covers the recurrent budget, the second 
covers investment expenditures under the public investment program. The lack of a medium-
term perspective in the recurrent budget preparation, and lack of a link between the two budget 
processes, leads to inaccurate and incomplete costing of sector programs. As a result, this often 
leads to mismatches in recurrent and investment expenditure plans.  
 
13.  There  is  no  medium-term,  bottom-up  budget  exercise  to  accompany  the  top-down 
approach underpinned by the MTFF.  Such an exercise  would properly  cost  and  evaluate 
expenditure programs and allocate scarce public resources to those that are most effective. 
 
14.  A significant portion of general government expenditure is not covered by the budget 
process. In addition, most budget organizations are allowed to supplement their finances by 
raising budget revenues and retaining part of them in extra-budgetary funds. As a consequence, 
policy decisions are often made without comprehensive analysis of the overall fiscal resource 
envelopes and expenditure requirements. 
 
15.  Until recently the budget was prepared using a classification system that did not permit 
independent functional and economic analysis. As there is a mix of functional elements and 
economic  categories  in  the  budget  classification,  proper  evaluation  and  accountability  in 
assessing  the  budget’s  effect  when  compared  against  government  policy  objectives  and 
priorities was not possible. 
 
16.  Budget  Execution.  Budget  execution  arrangements  are  fragmented,  resulting  in 
dispersal  of  cash  resources  and  weak  payment  control.  There  are  almost  50,000  budget 
organizations  controlling  over  100,000  bank  accounts,  mostly  in  commercial  banks.  Line 
ministries  have  poor  control  over  the  budget  organizations  that  operate  in  their  areas  of 
responsibility. Such organizational arrangements make it difficult for MOF to reconcile cash-
account balances and monitor budget execution effectively.  
  
17.  Budgetary monitoring and accounting is weak, and the system for fiscal reporting is 
elaborate but ineffective. Currently CBU submits a daily report on the aggregate cash position, 
while  line  ministries  prepare  a  monthly  report  on  cash  payments  (aggregated  by  broad 
economic  categories)  and  detailed  quarterly  reports  that  cover  both  cash  payments  and 
expenditures.  However,  this  reporting  system  is  not  sufficient  to  give  timely  and  complete 
information on budget execution, partly as the reports of the numerous spending units are 
prepared and processed manually. Such processing of reports is time consuming and as a 
result detailed information for each spending unit is often not available to MOF, making cash 
planning difficult.

4   
 
18.  There is a lack of  segregation of duties, i.e., separation between the release of the 
authority to spend and the release of cash to agencies, with cash being transferred to spending 
units through the system of bank accounts of line ministries. This procedure allows spending 
agencies and the intermediate government institutions to build up idle cash balances, and thus 
increases MOF’s gross-borrowing requirements. 
 
19.  The accounting and reporting system is weak and cumbersome. Budget organizations 
and MOF’s budget and financial departments in oblasts and rayons financed directly from MOF 
maintain their accounts in accordance with a COA prescribed by the Government of the former 
Soviet Union in 1986. A separate COA is issued to account for periodic cash releases to line 
ministries during the budget execution process. The budget and financial departments in oblasts 
and rayons use yet another COA to account for cash releases made to the budget organizations 
under their jurisdiction. The CBU, its regional branches, and accredited commercial banks 
continue to record and report on government cash transactions in accordance with a COA that 
captures  major  economic categories of expenditure and tax revenues by type of taxes.  In 
addition, much of the accounting and reporting is processed manually. Because there is no 
uniform COA for government operations at different levels of  Government, MOF is able to 
consolidate only  the  cash  account  for  the  central  government  on  a  regular  basis.  Budget 
organizations have to  reference other classification systems to account for and report other 
transaction flows and stocks. A detailed sector and subsector analysis is presented in Appendix 
2. 
 
2.  Government Initiatives and Opportunities 
20.  Since 2000 the Government has undertaken measures to address these weaknesses.  
  
21.  Legal  Framework.  The  parliament  approved  the  Budget  System  Law  (BSL)  in 
December 2000, providing a legal basis for budget management. The law sets out the process 
of preparation of the annual budgets by the national and subnational governments. It also lays 
down the parliamentary authority for setting public debt limits and provisions for giving state 
guarantees. The Treasury Law was passed in 2004, authorizing the creation of a Treasury. The 
main tasks provided for by the law include (i) control and management of the state budget cash 
resources, (ii) registration of contracts of budget organizations, (iii) accounting of all government 
transactions, (iv) servicing of public debt, and (v) execution of national government guarantees. 
The Treasury  Law  also  authorized  creation  of  TSA  at  CBU  to  hold  all  government  cash 
resources. During  subsequent  years,  the  Government has recognized the need for  further 
improvements in these laws and is committed to refining them, in particular by (i) harmonizing 
the BSL and Treasury Law on budget execution; (ii) providing for parliamentary appropriation of 
the state budget, and progressive provision for budget organization extra-budgetary funds; (iii) 
progressively improving disclosure of the state budget and budget organization extra-budgetary 
funds; (iv) eventually producing annual accounts, audited by independent external auditors; and 
(v) certifying and submitting reports to the parliament, and the publication of these reports. 
 
22.  Budget Preparation. A major step has been undertaken to improve the quality of the 
budget by preparing a  3-year MTFF in accordance with the essence of  the interim Welfare 
Improvement Strategy and Program. Starting with 2005, a rolling MTFF has been prepared, 
establishing  targets  for  revenues  and  expenditures  for  the  subsequent  3  years.  This  is 
consistent with medium-term projections  for GDP, ceilings for the budget deficit and public 
borrowing, as well as with other macroeconomic parameters. A working group consisting of 
representatives of MOF, the Ministry of Economy (MOE), and CBU has developed projections of

5 
 
main macroeconomic parameters, revenues, and expenditures for the state budget, and basic 
directions  for  budgetary  policy  for  2005–07,  thus  laying  the  foundation  for  an  MTBF  for 
expenditure consistent with the MTFF. As part of the reform process, sector expenditure ceilings 
were set for the first time in the 2005 budget. 
  
23.  Work has also begun to formulate the budget on the basis of programs and policy 
objectives rather than input norms. This is being done by the introduction of an experimental 
program budgeting process in selected ministries, including  the Ministry of  Education. This 
bottom-up approach will complement the top-down MTFF reform. 
 
24.  With external assistance, considerable work has been done in  developing a revised 
budget classification system. The revised classification is in line with best international practices 
as  laid  down  in  the  International  Monetary  Fund’s  (IMF’s)  Government  Finance  Statistics 
Manual (GFSM 2001). 
 
25.  It  will  take  some  years  before  this  fundamental  change  in  the  mode  of  budget 
preparation  becomes  comprehensive  and  systemized.  The  MTFF  process,  including  the 
process of setting sector expenditure ceilings, is still in the early stages of development and will 
require considerable  further  enhancement  using sound economic data  before it  can  meet 
accepted international standards. Development of the MTBF on a rolling basis will also require 
some  institutional  changes  and  capacity  building  of  relevant  institutions,  especially  line 
ministries, in understanding and formulating sector strategic policies and investment programs. 
 
26.  Budget Execution. The Government established a central Treasury in MOF following 
the passage of the Treasury Law in 2004. In April 2005, the Government began developing 
treasury  procedures  for  ex-ante checking of the expenditures of  budget organizations  and 
applying commitment controls by preregistration of contracts in two pilot regions (Tashkent city 
and Samarkand oblast) and their associated districts. 
 
27.  By the end of  2006 the pilot  program had been extended to six other regions and 
districts. Implementation of the treasury system to the remaining regions and districts is set to 
be completed by the end of 2007. Treasury offices have opened consolidated bank accounts, 
closing down the many bank accounts held by  budget organizations for budget operations in 
these  pilot  regions.  Treasury  operations  are  now  conducted  using  a  mix  of  manual  and 
information  technology  (IT)  systems  developed  in-house,  covering  limited  but  core 
functionalities. 
 
28.  In February 2007, the Government approved  the organizational structure and staffing 
plan for the central Treasury and treasury departments and branches in the oblasts and rayons,4 
and in March 2007 appointed the Head of Treasury. 
 
29.  PFM Reform Strategy. Recognizing that the reform is a long-term and complex task, 
the Government has begun to take a holistic, long-term view. In May 2007, MOF developed a 
PFM reform strategy for the period 2007–2018. As described in paras. 6-7, the strategy outlines 
an action plan for the next 12 years to develop a modern treasury system, implement a unified 
budget and accounting system, and introduce an MTBF and program budgeting in selected 
sectors.  An  important  element  of  the  strategy  is  to  develop  a  GFMIS  which  will  enable

In addition, the CSP attaches great importance to good governance in all ADB’s operations in

31.  The proposed Project is in line with the  essence of the CSP to support the country’s

5.  Lessons 
36.  Studies by ADB, previous ADB projects, and World Bank treasury projects  in other 
countries highlighted the following  lessons, which were  considered during the design of  the 
proposed Project. 
 
(i)  Government commitment to ownership of PFM reform. The Government is 
committed to PFM reform; as noted earlier, it initiated the reform process in 2000. 
Since then the reform has advanced steadily with external assistance and its own 
initiatives. The Presidential Resolution issued in February 2007, and the PFM 
reform strategy prepared by MOF in May 2007, have indicated the Government’s 
continued strong commitment to the reform.  
 
(ii)  Clear MOF ownership of the project design. The World Bank’s experience of 
treasury reforms in the Central Asia region  indicates the importance of careful 
project preparation that ensures clear understanding and ownership of the final 
project design by the implementing agency. During the project preparation, ADB 
missions discussed various aspects of the Project and reached an agreement 
with  MOF  on  its  objective,  scope  and  implementation  arrangements.  MOF 
worked  intensively  to  form  its  own  views  on  the  output  of  the  Project  and 
associated critical milestones and performance indicators.  
 
(iii)  Complementary TA to support the required capacity building. Previous ADB 
projects indicate the need to ensure sufficient TA resources  are available for 
capacity  building  because  of  the  complexity  and  iterative  nature  of  reform 
implementation. ADB’s special studies on its public expenditure management TA 
projects for selected countries and TA projects for Kazakhstan and  the Kyrgyz 
Republic, both carried out by the Operations Evaluation Department, indicated 
that (a) capacity building is a long-term task and needs long-term TA, and (b) TA 
projects should be designed with considerable understanding of the existing local 
capacity, gaps, and constraints to ensure it takes into account the context rather

8   
 
than addresses the issues separately and ineffectively. Partly based on these 
lessons, complementary TA is included as an integral part of the Project. The TA 
will be implemented within 2 years and will focus on addressing identified gaps 
and immediate needs  in budget preparation and execution using the revised 
budget classification. While the TA does not intend, and will not be able, to meet 
all  the  capacity-building  requirements,  it  is  designed  to  complement  other 
ongoing TA projects supported by other multilateral and bilateral agencies. It is 
also designed to leave plenty of room for future possible assistance by other 
development  partners.  If  necessary,  ADB  can  consider  providing  additional 
capacity-building support from its future operation program, as it will continue to 
consult with authorities on progress in PFM reform implementation.       
  
III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome  
37.  The project impact will be  improved planning and utilization of  public resources. The 
project outcome will be improved effectiveness, efficiency, transparency, and accountability of 
budget execution processes. The project impact and outcome will be monitored and measured 
mainly by the performance indicators as described earlier (paras. 9–10) and in the design and 
monitoring framework in Appendix 1.  
 
B.  Outputs and Components 
38.  Project outputs will comprise (i) establishment of a modern Treasury with a nationwide 
network  of  treasury  offices  servicing  budget  organizations  of  national  and  subnational 
governments and revenue collection agencies, and development of a functioning GFMIS to 
facilitate treasury operations;  (ii) consolidated and streamlined  treasury banking operations 
under the established TSA; (iii) creation of a central accounting system using a unified COA in 
line with  the revised budget classification, the GFSM 2001 and IPSAS; (iv) a refined legal 
framework; and (v) application of the revised budget classification to the budget preparation and 
execution with improved pilot program budgeting in selected sectors. 
 
39.  The Project will have three components: (i) establishment of a nationwide institutional 
network of treasury offices and support for  capacity building;  (ii)  modernization  of  treasury 
operations; and (iii) project management, monitoring, and evaluation. 
 
1.  Establishment of a  Nationwide Institutional Network  of Treasury Offices 
and Support for Capacity Building  
40.  This component will provide assistance for the establishment of a nationwide institutional 
network of treasury offices and associated capacity building in areas where gaps  have been 
identified and the needs are acute.  In particular, the capacity building will include support to 
build  MOF’s  capacity  in  the  maintenance  of  the  GFMIS  and  management  of  associated 
databases. 
 
41.  This component will include  two subcomponents, the first  being the  refurbishment of 
treasury offices. These treasury offices at regional and district levels will be established prior to 
the introduction of the GFMIS. The Government will finance the refurbishment in two phases,

with $5.8 million during 2008 and $4.2 million during 2009, out of its own resources  and in 
accordance with its procurement procedures. 
 
42.  The second subcomponent will provide specialized training and certification for about 10 
IT specialists from MOF in the GFMIS maintenance and associated database management. The 
training aspects will include (i) database administration, (ii)  operational systems engineering, 
and (iii) network technology engineering.  This training  will be provided by a specialized IT 
certification company  for the following reasons: (i)  the training will be completed  before the 
selection of the GFMIS vendor7 to build the capacity of treasury staff in the transition to a new 
treasury system and to coordinate with the GFMIS vendor during the software design and 
development phase, and (ii) there is a risk that the GFMIS vendor may not be able to provide 
training on all aspects required by MOF. The GFMIS vendor will be responsible for providing 
hands-on training for GFMIS functions, operation and maintenance. Therefore, the IT training 
and certification will be provided during the first year of project implementation in accordance 
with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time), under a 
contract between the PMO and an authorized IT certification company engaged on the basis of 
consultant’s qualifications selection method.  
2.  Modernization of Treasury Operations 
43.  This component will comprise development and implementation of a GFMIS. The GFMIS 
will include six procurement packages, outlined below. Treasury functions, GFMIS functionality

44.  Package 1: Development and implementation of GFMIS software. This includes the

Taxation Committee and State Customs Committee; (iv) development of user documentation 
and training modules in local languages; (v) installation, testing and deployment of the GFMIS in

67.  A grant TA project of up to $600,000 will be provided as an integral part of the Project,

68.  The impact of the TA project will be improved budget preparation and execution under a

project will be strengthened capacity of the Government in budget preparation and execution 
using the revised budget classification. The TA project is to address immediate capacity-building

While the TA project will aim to have a nationwide impact, its training program will pay special 
attention to strengthening the capacity of relevant staff from MOF’s  Treasury, local  treasury 
offices, Budget Department, MOE, and line ministries selected for pilot program budgeting.  
 
69.  The TA project will have two components: (i) support  for budget preparation, and (ii) 
support for budget execution through  treasury operations using the GFMIS. The TA project 
outputs will comprise (i) development of  user manuals on  budget preparation and  treasury

71.  The TA project will be implemented over a period of 24 months, starting in January

V.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Economic and Financial Analyses 
72.  The main economic  benefits  of  the  Project  are  indirect  and  will  be  reflected in  (i) 
improved budget quality, (ii) budget execution efficiency and linkage between budgeting and 
policy objectives as well as program outcomes, (iii) greater transparency and accountability in 
PFM underpinned by the established treasury institutional network and modern treasury system, 
and (iv) progress in the introduction of the MTBF and program budgeting. The direct economic 
benefits of the Project are the savings derived from better cash management and thus reduced 
interest payments. 
73.  The beneficiaries of the Project include (i) policy makers and institutions who, with the 
help of the modern treasury, will be able to make decisions and, if necessary, fiscal adjustments 
based on the timely availability of better-classified information; (ii) stakeholders, including the 
general public and parliament, who will be able to better assess and monitor the effect of public 
finance management; and (iii) the general public, which will benefit from the provision of public 
goods and services that are facilitated by improved payment and budget execution processes. 
 
B.  Involuntary Resettlement, Indigenous People, and Environmental Assessment

it  lead  to  any  issues  affecting  indigenous  people  as  no  project  activities  would  imply

development of local area networking will be carried out in strict compliance with applicable 
local legislation and will be subject to environmental monitoring by an authorized environmental 
agency.  Thus,  it  is  anticipated  that  the  Project is  unlikely  to have  any significant adverse 
environmental impacts.

SECTOR AND SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
A.   Macroeconomic Adjustments 
  
1.  Macroeconomic management has improved significantly in recent years, as fiscal and 
monetary policies  have been tightened, a zero net-external-borrowing policy introduced, and 
lending from the  Central  Bank  of  Uzbekistan (CBU) to  the  budget  discontinued.  This  has 
supported  the  unification  of  exchange  rates  and  the  formal  introduction  of  convertibility  in 
October 2003, which has removed one of the main obstacles to private investment. There has 
also been a policy of progressively hardening budget constraints for state enterprises, through 
measures such as the use of energy and utility tariff increases, mandatory prepayments for 
power and gas consumers, and stronger efforts to boost collection. As a result, the quasi fiscal 
deficit in the energy sector has been significantly reduced, although tariff adjustments have also 
begun to adversely affect lower-income groups, particularly in urban areas.  
 
2.  By  2006,  Uzbekistan  had  achieved  significant  fiscal  improvement.  Government 
expenditure had been reduced from  about 45% of gross domestic product (GDP) in 1998 to 
about 32% in 2006, and fiscal deficits had been eliminated by 2006 after having reached 10% in 
1998-99.  
 
3.  Consistent with tighter fiscal policy, real-exchange-rate devaluation in the period leading 
up to the unification of the exchange rates, and continued administrative restrictions against 
imports, the external balance has improved significantly over the past 3 years. The current 
account moved from a position of small deficits in the late 1990s to a surplus of 19.5% of GDP 
in 2006, and reserves have risen since 2001  to reach about the equivalent of 12 months of 
imports in 2006. High prices for Uzbekistan’s two key export commodities, cotton and gold, have 
supported this turnaround, as have rising gas exports to the Russian Federation. Following real-
exchange-rate depreciation over the period 2000–2002, the ratio of external debt to GDP has 
declined significantly. Provided that the current tight external borrowing policies are maintained, 
the debt-to-GDP ratio should decline to about 24% by the end of the decade, and the debt-
service-to-exports ratio to about 10%. Nonetheless, the economic growth recorded in recent 
years has not been sufficient to improve the economic welfare of much of the population with 
low incomes.  
 
B.   Public Finance Management 
 
4.  The authorities recognize that there are serious weaknesses in budget preparation and 
execution in Uzbekistan. These are common to all countries that inherited their public finance 
management systems from the former Soviet Union.  
 
  1.  Budget Preparation 
 
5.  Lack of Medium-Term Perspectives and Weak Links with Policy Objectives: The 
Government has been conscious of the weaknesses in the preparation of annual budgets. Most 
fiscal decisions in Uzbekistan are taken within the tight time constraints of the annual budget 
calendar. The  Ministry of Finance (MOF) receives budget requests from 13 ministries, more 
than 180 independent agencies of the state budget as well as the 14 regions that consolidate 
the  budget  request  of  213  rayons  (districts).  The  Cabinet  of  Ministers  indicates  areas  of 
particular priority, such as education, at the beginning of the budget preparation process. MOF 
reviews the budget requests in terms of their consistency with current regulations, and applies

cuts mainly to the fourth category of expenditure,10 which often leads to a lack of funds for 
maintenance and current supplies. However, the available time and data do not give MOF the 
opportunity to undertake in-depth analysis of the links between proposed or existing economic 
policies and the state budget scenarios.  
 
6.  Until recently the budget has also suffered from lack of a medium-term perspective, such 
as the preparation of a macroeconomic framework that would project important macroeconomic 
variables—including GDP, balance of payments, inflation, and interest rates—over a 3–5-year 
period.  Such  a  macroeconomic  framework  would  form  the  basis  for  more reliable revenue 
estimates. In combination with  the government’s deficit target, the revenue estimates would 
impose an overall spending limit and allow for the establishment of sector spending limits, and a 
coherent and sustainable aggregate and sector expenditure policy. 
 
7.  For the top-down approach and sector spending limits to be meaningful and sustainable 
rather than arbitrary and transient,  they need to be combined with  a bottom-up exercise that 
properly costs and evaluates expenditure programs and allocates scarce resources to those 
that are most effective. Currently the budget entities prepare their budget requests on the basis 
of input norms rather than on clear policies and policy objectives linked to defined programs with 
performance indicators.  
 
8.  A major step has been taken to improve the quality of budget by preparing a  3-year 
medium-term fiscal framework (MTFF) in accordance with the Interim Welfare Improvement 
Strategy  and  Program  (IWISP).  Starting  with  2005,  a  rolling  MTFF  has  been  prepared, 
establishing targets for revenues and expenditures for the next 3 years, consistent with the 
medium-term projections of GDP, ceilings for the budget deficit and public borrowing, as well as 
with other macroeconomic parameters. A working group consisting of representatives of MOF, 
the Ministry of Economy (MOE), and CBU has developed projections of main macroeconomic 
parameters,  revenues,  and  expenditures  of  the  state  budget,  and  basic  directions  of  the 
budgetary policy for 2005–2007, laying the foundation for a  medium-term budget framework 
(MTBF) consistent with the MTFF. In the 2005 budget, sector expenditure ceilings were set for 
the first time. Work has begun to formulate the budget on the basis of programs and policy 
objectives rather than input norms by introducing an experimental program budgeting process in 
selected ministries. It will, however, take some years before this fundamental change in the 
mode of budget preparation becomes comprehensive and systemized.  
 
9.  The greatest challenges for the preparation of an MTBF are to (i) develop institutional 
mechanisms to link policymaking to budgeting, (ii) enhance the capacity in the formulation of 
economic policies, and (iii) improve the quality and reliability of the main economic data. The 
MTFF process, including the process of setting expenditure ceilings, is at an early stage of 
development. It will require considerable further enhancement  to meet accepted international 
standards in medium-term budgeting. 
 
10.  Outdated Classification  Structure.  As  there  has  been  a  mixing  of  functional  and 
economic categories in the classification, the budget has been prepared using a classification 
system  that  does  not  have  independent  functional  or  economic  analysis.  Accordingly,  the 
classification is not in line with the international standard laid down in the International Monetary 
Fund’s (IMF’s) Government Finance Statistics Manual (GFSM 2001), thereby undermining the 
development of a public finance management (PFM) system that can be benchmarked against 
international best practices.

13.  Most budget organizations are allowed to supplement their budget revenues by raising 
additional revenues and retaining  them in extra-budgetary funds. It has been estimated that

currently not included in the budget. 
 
14.  As a result, the budget is fragmented, and integrated policy decision making, budget 
preparation and budget execution are undermined. The authorities recognize this problem and 
are committed to integrating the budgetary system as a fundamental component of improving 
the  quality  of  the  public  finance  management  system,  and  hence  its  effectiveness  and 
efficiency.  
 
15.  Lack of Transparency. Budget documentation, including detailed budget and line-item 
expenditures, as well as planned policies regarding revenue and expenditures, has not been 
made public until recently. The authorities have begun publishing summaries of the approved

budgets since 2004 and adopting a more detailed breakdown  of budget execution. They are 
committed to extending the level of detail of budget data to be published in future. 
 
16.  Institutional Weaknesses Impeding Budget Preparation Reform. The lead agency 
for the investment budget, responsible for the Public Investment Program (PIP), is not MOF but 
MOE. Although MOF officials are involved in the formulation of the PIP and all projects are 
formally subject to a process of appraisal, they are not evaluated together with other public 
resources being assigned to a particular sector, within the sector’s budgetary envelope. In 
addition, key decisions in the PIP are taken outside the formal budget process (for example, a-
priori decisions on the number of schools and hospitals to be constructed). There is minimal 
involvement and hence accountability of line ministries in investment budget preparation and 
execution.  
 
17.  The  budgetary  preparation  functions  of  MOF  are  distributed  across  a  number  of 
departments reporting to different  deputy  ministers,  who  are  also responsible for functions 
unrelated to budget preparation. Moreover, MOF does not have a separate department for 
macroeconomic analysis and forecasting, which will be necessary for MOF to be able to both 
give informed policy advice on fiscal policy and to form a basis for the development of the 
resource envelope for the budget. The authorities recognize these problems and are adopting a 
gradual approach to their resolution.  
 
  2.  Budget Execution 
 
18.  There  are  thousands  of  bank  accounts  in  use  outside  MOF’s  control,  resulting  in 
fragmentation  of  cash  resources  and  poor  payment  control.  Current  organizational 
arrangements  make  effective  monitoring  of  budget  execution  impossible.  There  are 
approximately 50,000 budget organizations operating over 100,000 of their own bank accounts, 
mostly in commercial banks, for both budgetary and extra-budgetary funds. Line ministries have 
weak control over the budget organizations that operate in their areas of responsibility, and  
MOF does not have a full inventory of these accounts. 
 
19.  There is a lack of segregation of duties between the release of the authority to spend 
and the release of cash to spending units, with cash being transferred to budget organizations 
by crediting their bank accounts. These procedures allow spending agencies to build up idle 
cash balances, thus increasing MOF's gross-borrowing requirement. 
 
20.  In principle, budget funds are released to budget organizations on the basis of monthly 
expenditure plans prepared after the adoption of the budget, but to keep cash under control 
these releases are not automatic and are  prioritized by MOF, which issues a certificate to 
authorize them. Cash management is currently focused on the distribution of cash to settle 
different categories of payables. Strenuous efforts are made to ensure that wages, salaries and 
similar payments that represent income to individuals are paid either on time or within a few 
days  of  the  due  dates,  including  by  arranging  short-term  loans.  The  situation  has  been 
aggravated by CBU’s rationing of cash in the banking system. The result has been that although 
funds  are  made  available  through  the  banking  system  to  budget  organizations,  these 
organizations are unable to make payments in cash to final recipients. The result has been that, 
particularly  outside  Tashkent,  arrears  of  two  or  more  months  have  occurred  in  wage and 
pension payments.  
 
21.  Because of the multitude of bank accounts and the ways in which they are funded and 
used, there is no direct coordination of bank balances in order to optimize the application of the 
aggregate cash available to MOF. The existence of budget organizations’ extra-budgetary funds 
(with independent receipts, payments and bank accounts) exacerbates MOF’s  difficulties in

trying  to  optimize  cash  management.  The  authorities  recognize  these  problems  and  are 
committed to introducing a comprehensive treasury single account (TSA) system for the general 
government sector and systematic cash planning and management. 
 
22.  Weak and  Cumbersome Accounting and Reporting. Budget organizations, MOF’s 
financial departments in  oblasts and  rayons, and line ministries financed directly from MOF 
maintain  their  accounts  in  accordance  with  a  chart  of  accounts  (COA)  prescribed  by  the 
government of the former Soviet Union in 1986. A separate COA is issued to account for such 
periodic cash releases to line ministries during the budget execution process. The financial 
departments in oblasts (regions) and rayons (districts) use yet another COA to account for the 
cash releases made by them to the budget organizations under their jurisdiction. The CBU, its 
regional  branches,  and  accredited  commercial  banks  continue  to  record  and  report  on 
government  cash  transactions  in  accordance  with  a  COA  that  captures  major  economic 
categories of expenditure and tax revenues by types of taxes. Many of the accounting and 
reporting operations are performed manually, reducing their timeliness and accuracy.  
 
23.  Because  there  is  no  uniform  COA  for  government  operations  at  different  levels  of 
government, MOF is able to consolidate only the cash account of the central government on a 
regular basis. In order to be able to account for and report transactions, other flows, and stocks, 
budget organizations have to reference other classification systems. This reduces the speed 
and  accuracy  of  their  accounting,  including  reconciliation.  The  authorities  recognize  these 
problems  and  have  approved  a  unified  COA  to  be  used  until  the  new  GFMIS  allows 
comprehensive and timely accounting and reporting.  
  3.  State of Internal and External Audit 
 
24.  The Control and Revision Department in MOF and its territorial divisions in oblasts are 
responsible for internal auditing. Its current role includes monitoring compliance with budgets 
and other financial legislation and regulation, in particular  (i) the timeliness and priority of 
payments, (ii) the targeted application of expenditures, and (iii) the observance of expenditure 
limits. Modern internal audit process, with its focus on mitigating risks, has a much broader 
focus than this.  
 
25.  In  general,  international  internal  audit  standards  are  designed  to  complement 
international external audit standards. In Uzbekistan, the Chamber of Accounts was established 
as the supreme  audit institution in mid-2002 (revised in 2005), but there is no provision for 
adherence to international external auditing standards. The Chamber of Accounts reports to the 
president and parliament, but it is not envisaged that its reports will be published. It currently 
has a staff of about 20 people and it is expected that this will be increased to 60. Much of its 
work is carried out  using staff of the Control and Revision Department and private auditing 
companies. Membership of the Chamber of Accounts board consists of 13 senior ministers and 
officials, with only two members from the parliament. 
  
26.  While steps are needed to strengthen internal audit functioning (starting with MOF) and 
introduce international internal audit standards, there is also a need to enhance the role of the 
Chamber of Accounts if it is to function as an effective external audit agency according to 
international benchmarks. Its institutional capacity needs to be substantially increased and its 
independence from executive needs assured.

C.  Public Finance Management Reform Strategy 
 
27.  The Government recognizes the problems arising from the fragmented nature of the 
budget and has assured that these issues will be addressed under the proposed PFM reform 
initiative. The PFM reform strategy  has been developed by MOF with inputs from  the Fiscal 
Affairs Department of IMF and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to comprehensively address 
the modernization issues of budget preparation and budget execution. A central element of the 
reform is the plan to set up a modern treasury system to replace the current budget execution 
system, which is dependent on the transfer of resources through thousands of bank accounts. 
 
1.  Legal Framework 
 
28.  The Budget System Law, approved in December 2000, provides a basic legal framework 
for fiscal management. It sets out the process of preparation of the annual budgets by the 
national and subnational governments, their consolidation into a state budget, and a timetable 
for submission of budget documents and adoption of uniform functional, organizational and 
economic classification. It also lays down the parliamentary authority for setting public debt 
limits  and  provisions  for  giving  state  guarantees.  Some  flexibility  is  also  provided  to  the 
executive for amending the budget appropriations during execution.  
 
29.  In August 2004, the country passed a  law on treasury execution of the state budget 
(Treasury Law), aimed at creating a central Treasury in MOF to service national and subnational 
government budget organizations. The main tasks of the  Treasury provided for by the law 
include (i) control and management of the cash resources of the state budget, (ii) registration of 
contracts of  budget organizations, (iii) accounting for all government transactions,  (iv) the 
servicing of public debt, and (v) the execution of national government guarantees. The law also 
authorized creation of a TSA at the central bank to hold all government cash resources. 
 
30.  There was also a decree issued in April 2005 which had the objective of strengthening 
the organizational activity of the Chamber of Accounts. The chamber was established in 2002 
for external monitoring of execution of the  state budget and to report on the results to the 
president and the two chambers of parliament (Oliy Majlis), thereby creating an external audit 
institution. However, the Chamber of Accounts comprises 13 senior ministers and government 
officials with only  one member being drawn from each house of the parliament, and so has 
limited institutional support. 
 
31.  Review of Statutory Framework. The Government recognizes the need for review of 
the existing legislation on budget preparation, external  audit, and treasury operations in  the 
context of the reform dynamics. Amendments to ensure the following are under consideration: 
 
(i)  harmonization  of  the  Budget  System  Law  and  the  Treasury  Law on budget 
execution; 
 
(ii)  provision for parliamentary appropriation of the state budget, and progressive 
provision for budget organization extra-budgetary funds; 
 
(iii)  permission  for  MOF  to  reduce  the  appropriations  if  financial  exigencies  so 
require; 
 
(iv)  progressive  improvement  in  disclosure  of  the  state  budget  and  budget 
organization extra-budgetary funds; and

auditors; certification and submission of reports to the parliament, and publication 
of the reports.

32.  Budget Classification. The revised budget classification system based on the GFSM 
2001  has  been  prepared  with  external  technical  assistance.  The  training  needs  for  the

A.  INTRODUCTION AND OVERVIEW 
1.1   Purpose 
The President of the Republic of Uzbekistan has during recent years directed the executive 
authorities to undertake actions to design and execute a Public Financial Management (PFM) 
reform strategy.  
 
The purpose of this information document, which has been approved by the Minister of Finance, 
is to: 
 
•  Summarize the strategy; 
 
•  Identify the reform priorities and sequencing of reform measures in order to guide the 
Ministry of Finance (MOF) in the execution of the strategy; and 
 
•  Set out the PFM reform action plan.  
 
1.2   Ultimate Objective 
The ultimate objective of the PFM strategy is to improve control over the PFM system in the 
Republic of Uzbekistan. Improved control is necessary to: 
 
•  Allocate resources in accordance with the priorities and policies of the Government of 
Uzbekistan; 
 
•  Deliver services efficiently in terms of the use of resources; 
 
•  Maintain aggregate fiscal discipline.  
 
1.3   Intermediate Objective 
The intermediate objective is to modernize key processes in the PFM system via the: 
 
•  Establishment of a modern centralized treasury system;  
 
•  Introduction of a modern, comprehensive and unified budget and accounting system 
including a new budget classification and a new chart of accounts (COA); and 
 
•  Introduction of a medium-term budget framework (MTBF) and program budgeting.  
 
1.4   Timeframe 
The  strategy  envisages  reform  actions  until  2018.  This  is  the  currently  planned  date  for 
completing  the  phasing-in  of  international  public  sector  accounting  standards  (IPSAS). 
However, it is possible that the end date of 2018 will change, for example if the accounting 
standards are phased in more quickly or slowly than currently envisaged, or if further reform 
measures are decided on.

B.  CENTRALIZED TREASURY SYSTEM 
2.1  Establishment of Treasury 
The Department for Methodology and Introduction of Treasury Execution for the State Budget 
was established in May 2005 in order to introduce progressively the Treasury execution system 
for the State Budget. Its operations now cover the whole country and it is planned to cover all 
budgetary expenditures by December 31, 2007. The President’s Resolution #594 of February 
28, 2007 established the MOF Treasury on the basis of this Department. 
  
2.2   Benefits of Treasury Establishment  
The MOF plans to improve control over the PFM system via the establishment of the Treasury 
by: 
 
•  Improved control over cash by consolidating government banking arrangements and 
introducing systematic cash planning and management. Currently, budget organizations 
have their own bank accounts in commercial banks, the MOF does not receive accurate 
and timely information on Government cash flows and balances, and therefore system-
wide control over cash is loose;12 
 
•  Improved control over payments, ensuring that they conform to appropriations. Final 
control over payments has been exercised by commercial banks and has been loose 
because  of  weak  institutional  relationships  (bank-client  relationship,  lack  of 
accountability of banks to the MOF) and technical infrastructure (broad budget economic 
classification, paper-based information systems);

4.2  MTBF and Program Budgeting  
A pre-pilot MTBF was used by the MOF in 2004, assisting it to identify the consequences of 
fiscal policy in future years and the impact of new policies on expenditure baselines. The MTBF 
process is planned to be extended in 2008 budget preparation into a full pilot. This is planned to 
be initially predominantly a top-down exercise (the Medium-Term Financial Framework [MTFF]) 
involving the MOF and the Ministry of Economy (MOE) to ensure the sustainability of the annual 
budget, better integration of capital and current  expenditure budgeting and to derive financial 
ceilings for annual budget proposals. 
 
It is also planned that line ministries will introduce the MTBF in 2008 budget preparation on the 
basis of pilot programs, on a bottom-up basis. This will build on the pre-pilot, in the MOF and 
selected line ministries, to give policy objectives, priorities and results greater emphasis in 
budget proposals and to de-emphasize the use of cost norms. It is not intended to introduce 
program budgeting fully until after the successful implementation of the full pilot and with the 
introduction of the new Treasury system including the GFMIS, currently planned to be January 
1, 2011. 
 
4.3   Appropriation System   
The MOF plans to introduce appropriations of expenditure by the Oliy Majlis, on a cash basis, at 
the time the new budget classifications are introduced. It is planned that appropriation by the 
Oliy Majlis will cover the republican, oblast and rayon budgets as currently defined, plus the 
budgets of State Targeted Funds (STFs) and the extra-budgetary funds of budget organizations 
(BO-EBFs). The MOF expects that Oliy Majlis appropriation will improve control of expenditure.  
 
It is planned that the appropriation of expenditure by the Oliy Majlis will be at more aggregated 
levels  of  the  classifications,  and  that  these  appropriations  will  be  disaggregated  into  more 
detailed budget allocations approved by the Cabinet of Ministers. 
 
It is not planned to appropriate by programs until program budgeting is implemented fully. The 
application of the appropriation system to STFs and BO-EBFs is planned to be progressive.  
 
4.4  Inter-governmental Fiscal Relationships 
The MOF plans to develop clearer legal and institutional distinctions between different levels of 
government, basing revenue shares and transfers to regional and local governments on more 
stable and predictable criteria. The MOF expects that this would improve control. The MOF also 
expects  that  the  introduction  of  program  budgeting  will  have  a  significant  impact  on  the 
distribution of policy responsibilities, and hence on the distribution of expenditure responsibilities 
as between central and local government. Accordingly, the MOF plans to commence a review of 
inter-governmental fiscal relations once the  shape of the future program budgeting system 
becomes clearer. 
 
4.5  Disclosure of Budget and Financial Information 
Since the 2003 budget execution report, the budget and budget execution reports have been 
published on a summary basis.  Over the next decade, planned changes in the structure of the 
budget  and  improvements  in  the  availability  of  budget  and  related  information  will  require 
frequent fresh decisions to be made on the detail of the information to be disclosed to the Oliy

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR  
SUPPORTING PUBLIC FINANCE MANAGEMENT REFORM 
 
A.   Background 
 
1.  The Government initiated public finance management (PFM) reform in 2000. Since then 
the Government has undertaken a number of steps to advance the reform process. One of 
these steps was the development of a PFM reform strategy for 2007–2018 by the Ministry of 
Finance (MOF) in April 2007. The strategy outlines an action plan for the next 12 years to (i) 
establish a functioning treasury system, (ii) adopt and implement a modern unified budget and 
accounting system, and (iii) introduce a medium-term budget framework (MTBF) and program 
budget. 
 
2.  A central element of the PFM reform is to improve budget execution process significantly 
over the next 5 years. The strategy plans to set up a nationwide network of treasury offices with 
a central treasury in MOF, local treasury departments at regional1 (oblast) level and branches at 
district (rayon) level. These treasury offices will provide services to the budget organizations of 
both  national  and  subnational  governments.  The  currently  fragmented  treasury  banking 
operations  will  be  consolidated  under  a  treasury  single  account  at  the  Central  Bank  of 
Uzbekistan, supported by a computerized information system. 
 
3.  Some of the preparatory work is already underway. Since April 2005, pilot treasury 
operations with limited but core functionalities have started in Tashkent city and Samarkand 
oblast and their associated district treasuries. These functionalities include procedures for ex-
ante checking of budget organization expenditures and application of commitment controls by 
preregistration of budget organization contracts. The pilot program extended to six other regions 
by the end of 2006, and there are plans to further cover the whole country. 
  
4.  MOF  has  done  the  groundwork  for  development  of  an  integrated  IT  system  (the 
government financial management information system [GFMIS]) for use by all treasury branch 
offices and the central treasury. The GFMIS will enhance the treasury functions, substantially 
changing business processes. It will help to (i) streamline treasury banking and single–account 
operations, (ii) release budget appropriations according to financial plans and use cash-flow 
forecasting to smooth payment financing, and (iii) create a central accounting system using a 
chart of accounts built to reflect the revised budget classification in line with the Government 
Finance  Statistics  Manual  (GFSM  2001)  and  the  International  Public  Sector  Accounting 
Standards and off-budget flows. The GFMIS will also have a report generation facility to meet 
budget  performance  needs  for  in-year  adjustments  and  policy  analysis.  It  will  also  assist 
promotion of the quality of annual budgets by its timely reporting on fiscal performance, and 
provide data for checking validity of assumptions, time-series comparisons, and trend analysis 
for the medium-term budget framework (MTBF). 
 
5.  Over the same period, the Government has also undertaken steps to improve the quality 
of the budget. In 2005, a  medium-term fiscal framework (MTFF) was prepared, establishing 
targets for revenues and expenditures for the next  3 years consistent with the medium-term 
projections of gross domestic product (GDP). A working group consisting of representatives of 
MOF, Ministry of Economy and the Central Bank of Uzbekistan developed projections of main 
macroeconomic  parameters,  revenues,  and  expenditures  of  the  state  budget,  and  basic

directions of the budgetary policy for 2005–2007, laying the foundation for an MTBF consistent 
with the MTFF.  
 
6.  Work  has  also  begun  to  formulate  the  budget  on  the  basis  of  output  and  policy 
objectives rather than input norms. An experimental budgeting program is being introduced in 
selected  ministries.  Considerable  work  has  been  done  in  developing  a  revised  budget 
classification system in line with international standards as laid down in the GFSM 2001. This 
includes development of a unified chart of accounts to reflect the revised budget classification 
and detailed accounting instructions 
 
B.   Technical Assistance Impact, Outcome, Outputs and Components 
 
7.  The impact of the technical assistance (TA) project will be improved budget preparation 
and execution under a budget classification consistent with international best practices, and 
improved  linkage  between  budgeting  and  policy  objectives  and  investment  programs.  The 
outcome  of  the  TA  project  will  be  strengthened  capacity  of  the  Government  in  budget 
preparation and execution using the revised budget classification. The TA project is to address 
the immediate capacity-building needs and focus on the areas not covered by other donors 
either now or in the near future. While the TA project will aim to have a nationwide impact, its 
training program will pay special attention to strengthening the capacity of relevant staff from 
MOF, Treasury, local treasury offices, Budget Department, MOE, and line ministries selected for 
pilot program budgeting.  
 
8.  The TA project will have two components: (i) support for budget preparation, and (ii) 
support for budget execution through  treasury operations using the GFMIS. The TA project 
outputs will comprise (i) development of  user manuals on budget preparation and  treasury 
operation under the revised budget classification;  (ii)  development  of  training  modules  and 
materials in budget preparation and execution using the revised budget classification system; 
(iii) development of performance indicators for the education sector; and (iv) training of 17 staff 
from MOF, Treasury, Budget Department, and Treasury Training Center on budget preparation 
and execution based on the revised budget classification. 
 
C.   Implementation Arrangements

be the Executing Agency for the TA project. The TA project will require 24 person-months input

treasury operations. The consultants will be selected and engaged by the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The consultants will interact closely with staff of MOF, Treasury, the PMO for
